data.text: Should I Buy a Bicycle Alarm for Touring?

I was skeptical on buying one of these, even though they’re cheap, but I’ve been hearing surprisingly good reviews about these little alarms. I don’t normally carry a lock with me since I don’t leave my bike for long anywhere plus it’s extra weight for anything decently secure, so I figured I’d make the plunge on one these!
Wsdcam 113dB Bike Alarm Wireless Vibration Motion Sensor Waterproof Motorcycle Alarm with Remote

Function: Arming and disarming Adjusting touch sensitivity Changing the electrical bell sound. Searching vehicle. SOS functions Battery low indicate

amazon.com
They are not super load NOW, I guess I should change the batteries. The had set has a weird battery that is replaceable but might be difficult to find a replacement. I would say they are OK.

data.text: Based on videos, this lock can readily be cut with a cheap set of tin snips. It has its place, but I don't think I would trust it out of my sight even for a few seconds. One review suggests using it to secure your helmet to the frame of your bike, which seems like a perfect use case for it.

data.text: I agree. But some are more readily compromised than others. I think it's important for people to understand that the zip lock is only a small step above no lock. In rural or suburban areas It's probably fine. But anywhere else is a gamble.

data.text: FYI my garmin (530) works as an motion alarm. Arm it from the app. If the bike moves it makes an alarm noise on the bike, and alarms on your phone, as long as you are in BT range. The alarm is not overly loud, but works. Worthwhile knowing, if you have a garmin, just to check if your device has this. I use mine when I duck into a shop or toilet, and I feel it is a reasonably safe situation

But most people would back off at the first sound.
data.author: Mandy Parker

data.text: I wouldn't use it over a lock. I have a bike alarm and a lock. Generally I just use the lock. If I think there are people paying too much interest in my bike, when I get off it, I turn on the alarm too. If I am in a shop and I hear the alarm go, I can bolt outside. The alarm would also go off if people are tinkering with my bags. The one I use is 120 dB, acts as a rear light, and is rechargeable.

data.text: I have this and it saved me two nights from thieves. I can assure you it’s good. AND LOUD! Normally I don’t like to take precautions against this kind of behavior, it kind of kills the joy of suspicion. But after one bike getting stolen and another time all bags getting stolen, better safe than sorry. The logistics are the problem when you’re on a long tour, not the stolen things itself. Organizing it again, that was hell. Before this alarm I used a thin trip wire with small bells I hanged in my tent. Also a good option. I heard one person fall screaming one night, probably cut himself while trying to get to my gear/bike..

data.text: I frequently forget to disarm mine and it gives me quite a fright, and no small embarrassment. It’s very sensitive to the smallest movement. Luckily it only gives a short burst at first. It only makes a sustained alarm if you keep giggling the bike. The only trouble I have had with it was that on a very gusty day someone told me my bike kept squawking. I use the alarm in addition to a cable lock. The alarm deters people from removing stuff from my bike, like the trunk bag or lights.
data.author: Jeff Hiles

data.text: Through the years I used to have a few of the old ABC coded ones. Those were pretty bad, because rain dropping on it was enough to sound the alarm which made it unusable in those circumstances, if it still worked anyway... I ordered one of these with the remote control at the end of last year from another shop and took it on a trip. Pretty solid I must say, but I must have been unlucky with the one I had, because as soon I removed the plastic from the battery, as soon as I hold it upright the alarm sounded. So I had to place it in my handlebar bag for the whole trip. I still used it when parking for shopping etc, but removed the battery after the trip and sent it back for refund. I then bought one integrated in a rearlight. I haven't used it yet. Make sure to buy one with the remote control in a mount where it clicks in, because otherwise you are for sure going to lose the remote control sooner or later!
